questions.text: A group of scientists is studying a protein. They electrophorese the protein and transfer it to a membrane. The proteins are visualized by tagging them to specific antibodies. This procedure is called:
questions.solution:
The above procedure depicts Western blot technique. This technique is used to study protein molecules. The proteins undergo electrophoresis and then are transferred to a membrane. These proteins are then tagged with the specific antibodies and visualized. 

Northern blot technique is used to detect RNAs. The RNAs are separated by electrophoresis and then transferred to a membrane and bound to radiolabelled probes.

Southern blot technique is used to detect DNAs. In this technique, DNA is extracted from the cells and is cleaved into many fragments using a restriction enzyme. The resulting fragments are separated based on the size using electrophoresis. The DNA fragments are then denatured and transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane for analysis. The DNA fragment of interest is then identified using the specific DNA probe.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the proteasomal degradation of proteins?

choices.text: Misfolded proteins are degraded in this process.
Ubiquitin is the key molecule involved.

questions.solution:
Option D is the false statement. Proteasomal degradation of proteins is an ATP-dependent process.

The proteasome consists of a macromolecular, cylindrical complex of proteins. It consists of four rings with a hollow core containing the protease active sites, and one or two caps or regulatory particles. The regulatory particles recognize the polyubiquitinated substrates and initiate the degradation of the protein.

Ubiquitin is the key molecule in protein degradation. Degradation of regulatory proteins with short half-lives and of abnormal or misfolded proteins occurs in the cytosol, and this process requires both ATP and ubiquitin.

Bortezomib, carfilzomib, and ixazomib are proteasome inhibitors. They inhibit proteolytic degradation of multiple cellular proteins and are used in the treatment of multiple myeloma.

questions.text:
In a reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction test (RT-PCR), the target RNA strand that will undergo the process is 5' - AUGCUGCAGUCAAAAAA - 3'. Outputs obtained from the process are shown below. Choose the correct statement.
  1. "A" is the DNA strand obtained after replication of cDNA
  2. "B" is the cDNA strand obtained from RNA
  3. "C" is the cDNA strand obtained from RNA
  4. "D" is the DNA strand obtained after replication of cDNA
questions.solution:
For the given RNA strand, 5' - AUGCUGCAGUCAAAAAA - 3', the obtained complementary DNA strand will be as shown in image "C" following the rules of complementary base pairing (adenine binds with thymine/uracil and cytosine binds with guanine). The DNA strand obtained by replication of the cDNA strand will contain only thymine and not uracil and is therefore represented by "A" in the image above.

RT-PCR is a method that is used for the analysis of mRNA expression and its amplification.

Reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) is a variant of PCR and includes 2 steps:

  • Generation of complementary DNA (cDNA copies) from mRNA using reverse transcriptase - used to qualitatively detect gene expression
  • Amplification of newly synthesized cDNA by traditional PCR - This can be quantitatively measured by using fluorescent dyes (qRT-PCR).

Uses: 

  • Determination of viral load
  • Screening of genetic diseases and cancers

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is used in polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and is heat stable and obtained from bacteria?
questions.solution:
Taq polymerase is used in PCR. It is heat stable and is obtained from the bacteria Thermophilus aquaticus. It lacks a proofreading activity.

DNA synthesis in PCR is catalyzed by a heat-stable DNA polymerase. It is purified from thermophilic bacteria Thermophilus aquaticus, organisms that grow at 70 to 80°C. Thermostable DNA polymerases withstand short incubations at over 90°, temperatures required to completely denature DNA.

The technique of PCR:

Denaturation- sample DNA strands are separated by heating at 95℃ for 15 seconds to 2 minutes.

Annealing- the primers, added in vast excess, are allowed to anneal to the DNA (typically 50–75°C). The primers hybridize with their complementary single-stranded DNA.

Extension- each strand is copied by a Taq polymerase, starting at the primer sites in the presence of all four nucleotides (dNTPs) at 72℃.

The image given below shows the steps involved in PCR.


The image given below shows the resources required for PCR:


Other options:

Option A: DNA polymerase III is involved in the replication. This enzyme binds to template DNA to synthesize DNA in the 5' to 3' direction at the replication fork.

Option B: Endonuclease is involved in the replication. The mismatched base during replication is identified and removed by the endonuclease activity.

Option D: DNA gyrase is involved in the replication. It unwinds the DNA and relieves supercoils during replication. They act on the closed circular DNA of bacteria.

questions.text: Which of the following blot transfer techniques is used to detect protein-DNA interaction?
questions.solution:
South-western blot is used to detect protein-DNA interaction. 

South-western blot or overlay blot is used to examine protein-protein or protein-nucleic acid interactions respectively.

Other options:

Option A: Southern blotting is used for the detection of DNA.

Option B: Western blotting is used for the detection of protein.

Option C: Northern blotting is used for the detection of RNA.

questions.text: You are a biochemist working on various cytogenetic abnormality. You use the following cytogenetic technique to study the abnormality from a tissue specimen. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormality cannot be picked up by this technique?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an array - comparative genomic hybridization (CGH). This cytogenetic technique cannot detect balanced translocation.

Array-based Comparative Genomic Hybridization:

In array CGH, two genomes are compared. The test DNA and the reference DNA are labeled with two different fluorescent dyes (red and green respectively) and are added to a DNA chip spotted with the entire human genome.

  • If the contribution of both samples is equal for a given chromosomal region, then all spots on the array will fluoresce yellow.
  • If the test sample has amplification, that spot will fluoresce red
    • If the test sample has a deletion, that spot will fluoresce green

Uses of Array CGH:

  • To detect gene amplification
  • To detect gene deletion 
  • To detect copy number variations

Limitations:

Cannot detect balanced translocations. Reason being as follows:

If there is less DNA in the patient than the control for a particular probe, the a-CGH will show a deletion of material from the patient for that particular locus; if there is more DNA in the patient than the control for a particular probe, the a-CGH will show a gain of material from the patient for that locus. In a balanced translocation, there is no gain or loss of material, so the probes will show that the patient and the control have equal amounts of DNA in those translocated regions.

Other methods for molecular analysis of genetic alterations include:

  • Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH)
  • Southern blotting
  • SNP - single nucleotide polymorphisms genotyping arrays
  • Multiple ligation dependant probe assays (MLPA)

Related Pearl: Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)

It is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on a morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes.

The fluorescent probes are added to cells usually arrested in the metaphase stage of cell division (when every chromosome is separately).

Types of FISH:

1) Chromosomal painting: Each chromosome is identified by using a different colour of the fluorescent probe, however, each chromosome does not have a unique colour. Since the fluorescent dyes are limited.

2) Multicolour FISH: 23 distinct fluorescent colours made by mixing 5 fluorophores. Thus each chromosome is identified by a unique colour. It is also known as spectral karyotyping (SKY). It offers various advantages such as

  • Detects structural and numeric abnormalities in chromosomes.
  • Detects gene amplification and subtle microdeletions
  • Maps a newly isolated gene to its correct chromosomal loci

However, this process requires prior knowledge of the genes and chromosomes.

3) Interphase FISH: It is a rapid procedure of FISH, wherein growing cells are not needed. It is used in prenatal diagnosis and in tumour diagnosis.

The image shown is of a Multicolor FISH also known as Spectral karyotyping with a unique colour to each chromosome pair.

questions.text:
The basis of which of the following processes is depicted in the image below?

DNA- Deoxyribonucleic acid

RNA- Ribonucleic acid

mRNA- messenger RNA
questions.solution:
The process in the given image is RNA editing. 

RNA editing is the process by which the coding sequence of the mRNA is changed before translation by post-transcriptional modification.  

As a result, the mRNA template differs from the DNA from which it was transcribed. This leads to the formation of a different protein. This occurs by the insertion of additional uracils at the 3’ end of the mRNA and proceeds in the 3’ to 5’ direction.

The process of apolipoprotein B48 synthesis involves RNA editing.

RNA editing in apoB synthesis:
  • In the liver, the apoB gene is transcribed to mRNA, which is then translated to apoB-100.
  • In the intestine, the same apoB gene is transcribed to the same mRNA. But now, the mRNA undergoes editing by an enzyme cytidine deaminase, which converts the CAA codon in the mRNA to UAA at a single specific site. This edited mRNA translates to apoB-48.

The production of apolipoprotein (apo) B-48 in the intestine and apoB-100 in the liver is the result of RNA editing in the intestine. Here, a sense codon is changed to a nonsense codon by posttranscriptional deamination of cytosine to uracil.

DNA rearrangement, transposition, and alternate splicing also alter the gene expression but are not the basis of apoB-48 tissue-specific production.

questions.text: Pseudouridine and ribothymidine are present as nucleotides in _____.
questions.solution:
Pseudouridine and ribothymidine are present as nucleotides in transfer RNAs (tRNAs).

Transfer RNA is a type of RNA that helps to transport amino acids from the cell cytoplasm to the ribosome, where protein synthesis is taking place. Since they are soluble in nature, they are also known as soluble RNA (sRNA). They undergo internal base-pairing (represented by the black dotted lines in the image below) to form the secondary cloverleaf structure.

Each part of the cloverleaf structure serves a different purpose. The parts of the cloverleaf include:

  • Anticodon loop
  • Acceptor arm
  • D loop
  • The ribothymidine pseudouridine cytidine (TΨC) loop
  • Variable loop

The image given below shows the cloverleaf structure of tRNA.

The anticodon loop shown is where the anticodon triplet codons are present that make a tRNA specific. This anticodon will base pair with the complementary codon on the mRNA (messenger RNA) strand undergoing translation.

The acceptor arm is at the 3' end. This 3' end of the tRNA has the CCA sequence. The hydroxyl group on the A of the CCA sequence gets charged by accepting the amino acid specific to the codon (on the mRNA) that pairs with the anticodon loop. This then gets added to the elongating polypeptide chain. 

The D loop, TΨC loop, and variable loop are involved in defining the specific tRNA and ensuring accurate codon-anticodon base pairing.

Thus, a specific tRNA exists for each of the 20 amino acids that are commonly present in proteins. This tRNA acts as a mediator between the cytosolic amino acids and the mRNA strand undergoing translation.

Other options:

Option B: rRNAs (ribosomal RNA) are found within ribosomes and do not contain these modified bases.

Option C: hnRNA (heterogenous nuclear RNA) is processed to produce mRNA, which also lacks these modified bases.

Option D: snRNPs (small nuclear RNAs complexed with protein) are involved in splicing and also lack ribothymidine and pseudouridine.

questions.text: Which of the following methods uses specialized RT-PCR  to amplify the ends of mRNA transcripts?
questions.solution:
Rapid Amplification of cDNA Ends PCR, or RACE-PCR, is used to amplify the ends of messenger RNA (mRNA) transcripts using a specialized reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction.

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR is a rapid automated method for the amplification of specific DNA sequences (or genes). 

Reverse transcriptase PCR: The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complimentary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA, and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR.

Using the known information from the center of the transcript, RACE-PCR allows the amplification of an unknown end portion of the transcript via a specialized reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). RACE-PCR is also referred to as one-sided PCR or anchored PCR.

Other special PCR types:

Nested PCR: It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the target sequence for the second primer is present only on the amplicon with the target sequence. Nested PCR is intended to reduce non-specific binding due to the amplification of unexpected primer binding sites.

 

 

Multiplex PCR: Multiple primers are used to amplify several DNA sequences simultaneously. As this process targets multiple genes at once, a single test run gives additional information that would otherwise require several times the reagents and technician time to perform. 

Droplet digital PCR (ddPCR): ddPCR is an advanced and more precise type of quantitative PCR, which gives more consistent and reproducible results. It can accurately quantify the target nucleic acid sequence within a sample. It is useful for determining somatic mutation with low allele frequency. Mutant alleles of frequency as low as 0.25% can also be detected using this technique.

questions.text: A research fellow in biochemistry is studying the lac operon concept of gene regulation. He cultures E. coli. in a glucose-deficient and lactose-containing medium. Which of the following genes expressed in this condition helps convert lactose to galactose and glucose?
questions.solution:
The gene marked as 2 is the lac Z gene, which codes for β-galactosidase. This enzyme converts lactose to galactose and glucose.

Lac operon concept

Jacob and Monod studied the Lac operon model, which is the regulation of lactose metabolism by the intestinal bacterium Escherichia coli. It is switched on when the bacteria have to utilize lactose for utilization. Otherwise, it is switched off. It contains the following genes:

  • lac I- it codes for the repressor protein
  • cAMP response element (CRE)- It is activated by binding the cyclic AMP activator protein (CAP). When activated, it increases the binding of RNA polymerase and increases gene expression.
  • Promoter site- It is the site where RNA polymerase binds the gene for transcription. 
  • Operator site- It is the site where repressor protein binds.
  • lac Z gene- It codes for β-Galactosidase that hydrolyzes lactose to galactose and glucose. 
  • lac Y- It encodes for lactose permease, which increases the permeability of lactose into the cells.
  • lac A- It encodes for thiogalactoside transacetylase. 

For the working of Lac operon, the operator site should be free and the CRE site should be activated.

1. When glucose is present and lactose is absent- The bacteria utilize glucose. The lac I gene produces repressor protein, which binds to the operator site. Repressor-operator binding prevents the binding of RNA polymerase and, consequently, prevents transcription of the lacZ, lacY, and lacA structural genes into a polycistronic mRNA. 

In addition to this, excess glucose inhibits adenylyl cyclase. Therefore, the production of cAMP is reduced. Less cAMP means less cyclic AMP activator protein (CAP) binding to CRE. CRE is not activated, and lac operon is switched off.

2. When glucose is absent and lactose is present- Bacteria utilize lactose. The lactose inactivates the repressor protein. This prevents the binding of repressor protein to the operator site. The operator site is now free and RNA polymerase can start with the transcription. The low glucose level causes an increase in the adenylyl cyclase activity, and increases the cAMP levels. This increases the binding of CAP to CRE, which in turn activates the transcription of the lacZ, lacY, and lacA structural genes into polycistronic mRNA. 

3. When both glucose and lactose are present- The bacteria utilize glucose. The unused lactose binds to the repressor protein and renders it inactive. The operator site is free. However, the increased glucose level inhibits adenylyl cyclase and decreases the cAMP levels. Therefore, even though the operator site is free, CRE is not activated, which leads to the switching off of the lac operon.

questions.text: Which of the following acts as an RNA-directed nuclease?
questions.solution:
CRISPR-Cas9 acts as an RNA-directed nuclease.

Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats-associated gene 9, or CRISPR-Cas9, is a DNA editing/gene regulatory system. It involves two essential components: Cas9, an endonuclease that causes a double-stranded DNA break, allowing modifications to the genomic DNA to be made; and a synthetic single-guide RNA, or sgRNA, responsible for guiding Cas9 to its target.

Once the sgRNA has directed the Cas9 to the section of the genomic DNA to be edited, the 3’ end of the sgRNA comes to lie across a specific sequence of DNA adjacent to the editing side called the protospacer adjacent motif or PAM. The Cas9 now causes a double-stranded break in the DNA at the PAM site, which is then repaired by a non-homologous end-joining.

questions.text:
Which of the following methods are used for the detection of RNA?
  1. PCR
  2. Real-time PCR
  3. RT-PCR
  4. Northern blotting
  5. Western blotting
questions.solution:
The methods that can be used for the detection of RNA are northern blotting and RT-PCR (option D - 3, 4).

PCR (polymerase chain reaction) is a technique used to amplify a selected DNA sequence. It can be used to synthesize millions of copies of the selected DNA sequence in a few hours, enabling the detection of even trace amounts of DNA in a sample. Therefore, PCR is used for:

  • Detecting mutant DNA 
  • DNA fingerprinting for forensic analysis- Detection of DNA from small amounts of samples from the crime scene
  • Detection of latent viral infections
  • Carrier detection of cystic fibrosis

Real-time PCR is used for quantitation of the number of viruses present in a sample e.g. viral load in HIV or HBV. So, the treatment modalities can be planned and the response to treatment can be assessed.

RT-PCR or reverse transcriptase PCR is used for the detection of RNA. It can be used to quantitate mRNA levels by generating complementary DNA (cDNA) copies of the mRNA using the reverse transcriptase enzyme. 

The northern blot technique can also be used to detect RNAs. Here, the mixture of mRNA molecules is separated by electrophoresis and then transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane and hybridized with radiolabeled probes.

Western blot, also called immunoblots, is a technique used to study protein molecules. The proteins undergo electrophoresis and then are transferred to a membrane. These proteins are then tagged with the specific antibodies and visualized.

questions.text: A biochemist wanted to study the difference in gene expression between a cancer cell and a normal cell. He used the following method shown in the image. Identify the method.
questions.solution:
The method shown in the image is called microarray analysis. 

It can be used to study mutations in DNA and variations in gene expression.

It consists of a slide with tiny spots of DNA called a DNA (or gene) chip. For studying gene expression, mRNA is taken from the sample and then its complementary DNA (cDNA) is made. This cDNA from the normal cell is labeled with green fluorescence, and the cDNA from the cancer cell is labeled with red fluorescence. Then, both are allowed to hybridize with the DNA on the chip.

Interpretation:

  • Black spots represent no expression by both normal and cancer cells.
  • Red spots represent more expression by the cancer cells.
  • Green spots represent more expression by normal cells.
  • Yellow spots represent equal expression by both cells.

Using the microarray technique, the differing patterns of gene expression between two types of cells can be analyzed.

Option B - A northern blot only measures mRNA production from one gene at a time.
Option C - Southern blot can only analyze DNA not the products of DNA expression.
Option d - Western blot measures protein production.

questions.text:
Which of the following modifications occur posttranscriptionally to produce a mature eukaryotic mRNA?
  1. Capping
  2. Polyadenylation
  3. Phosphorylation
  4. Trimming
  5. Splicing
  6. Hydroxylation
questions.solution:
Capping, polyadenylation, and splicing are the modifications that occur posttranscriptionally to produce a mature eukaryotic mRNA. Phosphorylation, hydroxylation, and trimming are modifications that occur posttranslationally.

A mature eukaryotic mRNA is formed after the pre-mRNA components of the heterogenous nuclear RNA (hnRNA) undergo the following posttranscriptional modifications in the nucleus:

  1. Addition of a 5′ cap: A 7-methylguanosine is attached to the 5′ terminal end of the mRNA via a 5′-to-5′ triphosphate linkage. This stabilizes the mRNA and allows initiation of translation.
  2. Addition of a 3′-poly-A tail: The poly-A tail is added by the nuclear enzyme, polyadenylate polymerase, after clevage of the polyadenylation signal sequence (AAUAAA) found near the 3′ end of the mRNA. This terminates eukaryotic transcription. Furthermore, it stabilizes the mRNA, allows it to exit from the nucleus, and helps in translation.
  3. Splicing: This is the process of removing introns (intervening sequences that do not code for proteins) and joining exons (the coding or expressed sequences), carried out by the spliceosome. Alternative splicing occurs in different tissues to produce varied number of proteins from a limited set of genes.

questions.text: Best method for detection of mutations with low allele frequency is
questions.solution:
Best method for detection of mutation with low allele frequency is Droplet digital PCR (ddPCR)

It is an advanced and more precise type of quantitative PCR which gives more consistent and reproducible results. It can accurately quantify the target nucleic acid sequence within a sample. It is useful for determining somatic mutation with low allele frequency. Mutant alleles of frequency as low as 0.25% can also be detected using this technique. 

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is a rapid automated method for the amplification of specific DNA sequences (or genes). Reverse transcriptase PCR- The enzyme reverse transcriptase (RT) is used to synthesize a complimentary copy of DNA (cDNA) from RNA and this cDNA is then used as a template for PCR.

Other special PCR types:

Nested PCR- It involves the sequential use of two primer sets. The first primer set is used for amplification and the target sequence for the second primer is present only on the amplicon with the target sequence. Nested PCR is intended to reduce non-specific binding due to the amplification of unexpected primer binding sites.

Multiplex PCR- Multiple primers are used to amplify several DNA sequences simultaneously. As this process targets multiple genes at once, a single test run gives additional information that would otherwise require several times the reagents and technician time to perform. 

The Sanger sequencing technique is used for DNA sequencing. It is based on controlled termination of synthesis of DNA by using chain terminating agents like dideoxynucleotides.

Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH) is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes. FISH can be performed on prenatal samples, peripheral blood cells, touch preparations from cancer biopsies, and even fixed archival tissue sections.

questions.text: Which of the following technique is used to sequence proteins without prior purification?
questions.solution:
Tandem mass spectrometry can be used to sequence proteins without prior purification.

Tandem mass spectrometry involves two mass spectrometers linked in series. Individual peptides are separated by the first spectrometer based on the differences in mass of each peptide.

A single peptide is directed to the second mass spectrometer by adjusting the field strength of the first magnet. Here, it gets fragmented and the mass is determined.

It is used to screen the blood samples of newborns for genetic disorders such as phenylketonuria, ethylmalonic encephalopathy, and glutamic acidemia.

Other options:

Ion exchange chromatography, polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, and isoelectric focusing are the methods of purifying/separating proteins.

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis explains which of the following concepts of the genetic code?
questions.solution:
The wobble hypothesis explains the degeneracy of the genetic code.

The wobble hypothesis states that codon-anticodon pairing follows the traditional Watson–Crick rules (G pairs with C and A pairs with U) for the first two bases of the codon but can be less stringent for the third/last base. It has been observed that a tRNA can recognize more than one codon for a specific amino acid, especially in the last nucleotide of the codon triplet. This is referred to as degeneracy and its mechanism can be explained by the wobble hypothesis.

The first base of the anticodon moves to permit nontraditional pairing with the last base of the codon. This movement is called wobble and is possible because the first base of the anticodon is not as spatially defined as the other two bases. Due to the wobbling, 61 tRNA species are not required to read the 61 codons.

For example, three codons for glycine—GGU, GGC, and GGA—can form a base pair from one anticodon, 3′ CCI 5′ ie, I, inosine, can base pair with U, C, and A, as shown in the diagram below.

Other options:

Option A: The genetic code is universal because it is the same for all living organisms.

Option B: The genetic code is unambiguous because each codon is specific for only one amino acid. Example: GGA only codes for Glycine.

Option D: The genetic code is non-punctuated. This means that once the reading commences at a specific start codon, it is continuous and is read continuously as triplets until a stop codon is reached without stopping.

questions.text: Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) is used in order to identify the five different species of staphylococci in a surgical ICU. Which of the following site does the restriction enzyme act on?
questions.solution:
The restriction enzyme is likely to act on 5'-GATATC-3' (Option B).

Restriction endonuclease(RE) enzymes usually act at specific palindromic sequences which create DNA fragments of different lengths. A palindromic sequence is one that reads the same in opposite directions. By analyzing the fragments produced after cutting the DNA by RE, specific species of bacteria can be identified. Option B, when expanded after writing the complementary sequence, appears the same while reading both DNA strands in the 5' to 3' direction and is hence a palindrome.

5' --GATATC-- 3'
3' --CTATAG-- 5' 

Restriction endonucleases are enzymes that recognize and cleave a specific double-stranded DNA sequence. These DNA cuts result in sticky ends or blunt ends. Sticky ends are then used to build hybrid DNA. 

A Restriction fragment length poly­morphism (RFLP) is a genetic variant that can be studied by cleaving the DNA into fragments known as restriction fragments. This is done using a restriction enzyme. The length of the restriction fragments changes if the genetic variant alters the DNA and creates or abolishes the site of restriction endonuclease cleavage. RFLPs can thus be used to find the variation in different staphylococci species.

The sequences given in Options A, C and D are not palindromes, as they do not read the same forwards and backwards after expanding. So they cannot be recognized by Restriction endonuclease enzymes.

questions.text: Which of the following RNA is involved in mRNA splicing?
questions.solution:
snRNA or small nuclear RNA plays a role in mRNA splicing. They take part in the formation of spliceosomes.

Other options:

Option A: miRNA (micro RNA) is derived from large primary transcripts through specific nucleolytic processing. It modulates gene expression by altering mRNA function. They bind to matching pieces of mRNA, turn it into a double strand and arrest the translation. 

Option B:  rRNAs are involved in protein synthesis. They facilitate the interaction of mRNA, tRNA, and amino acids to interact with each other for the translation process. 

Option C: siRNA or interfering RNA is mainly involved in RNA interference. They degrade the mRNA through specific cytoplasmic organelles called P bodies.
